data.title: Loyalist Twp. / Bath, Ontario Bandscan
data.meta_description: This is the home of Explore Seoul and radio projects: 500 Top-of-Hour IDs, Seoul AM Radio Listening Guide, Songtan FM Radio Log, coastal propagation, and more.
data.meta_site_name: :: the online home of chris kadlec ::
data.text:
Go back to the Lake Ontario bandscan series | Return to the coastal bandscans index

Loyalist Township, including the village of Bath, is a radio site 10 miles west of Kingston on the north shore of Lake Ontario. The site, which was previously unplanned, came into being due to difficulties with an originally-planned site in Prince Edward County when Sandbanks was booked for the summer. Originally, Sandbanks would be the initial west-facing site with Prince Edward Point Bird Observatory, at the furthest southeastern point of the county, being both the east and south-facing site to compensate for blockage. Because of the change in plans, forcing the central site further west to Presqu’ile, these sites were no longer feasible due to time. For this reason, the Prince Edward County sites were called off with no plans otherwise. Loyalist Twp. became an impromptu site during a stop at Finkle’s Shore Park, a small historical roadside park with a gazebo (famous for the launching of the Frontenac and being the location of Finkle’s Tavern in 1786), a short walking trail, boat launch, food truck, and portable toilet. It’ll do! Interestingly, Loyalist Parkway – full of historic sites and plaques – follows Route 33 from near the Presqu’ile radio site all the way to this site.

Finkle’s Shore Park has just two miles of water to work with before running aground on sizable Amherst Island, meaning there is a primary land mass within view that is already blocking open water. Prince Edward County‘s peninsula, the very one with the bird observatory planned to operate for this very stretch of shoreline, blocks a direct path to all points west of Rochester (75 miles southwest), meaning signals from Buffalo (130 miles southwest), Hamilton (160 miles southwest), and especially Toronto (130 miles southwest) are dependent on refracted signals caught within the inversion duct or signals hopping over Prince Edward County entirely. Syracuse (80 miles southeast), Watertown (45 miles east), and Utica (100 miles southeast) are all wide open unobstructed water paths. With Kingston just 10 miles away, local interference would be expected to be rather heavy. On paper, it’s not a site I would ever choose given the numerous disadvantages unless I were desperate, but hey, let’s see what we can pull in here! (Hint: it worked out pretty well!)

LOYALIST TOWNSHIP / BATH, ONTARIO BANDSCAN

August 2, 2019 1540-1740 / 27°C, clear

Location: 44°10’19.3″N 76°47’21.1″W

at lake level in Finkle’s Shore Park

Recommendations for this radio site: When you pick a random little roadside park, you usually don’t expect a lot. For a radio site, it’s not especially perfect, but it has the basics. First off, there is often a food truck in the parking lot, and it’s worth a try! The gazebo can provide for some shelter and some trees immediately beside the water offer shade. Privacy here is hard to find due to the small nature of the park, but at the same time, the park isn’t especially busy. A portable toilet is on site if needed.

The site is close to services, with ample options just to the east in Kingston; the city’s beautiful downtown is just 15 miles away and an absolutely must-visit if you find yourself in this area. Bath is a historic town founded in 1784 – one of Ontario’s oldest – just a moment’s drive to the east of this park. It’s just a quick drive through, but this area is rich in history from the days of Upper Canada. Just the little roadside park has its own historical plaques and is full of history. The name “Loyalist” originates from the fact that this was the settlement of the United Empire Loyalists, those Americans who were loyal to the British cause and Crown during the American Revolution of the late 1700s, going against the goals of the colony’s fight for independence from Great Britain. The history of this cause lies all around the community. Primarily rural Amherst Island, which is a far more suitable substitute for this radio site, can be accessed by ferry from Millhaven, just to the east, with a fare of $10. Potential radio sites on this island include Back Beach Park (a 7-mile drive from the ferry in Stella) at the far southwest point of the island, or alternatively, the entrance to Sand Beach Wetlands Conservation Area (Third Concession at Beach Rd., the latter of which is typically closed to traffic) where a small turn-around can provide a public spot to set up that should be void of people. All other water-facing land on this large island is private. Listening on Amherst Island largely avoids the shadow of Prince Edward to the west.
